node.name: University of Alabama School of Medicine

activities_info.details: As the medical school transitions to the temporary online curriculum, students have been assisting by: volunteering to teach online lectures via ZOOM, help faculty and staff adjust to online media and platforms like ZOOM, and assist with tutoring and academic support for students in other classes.

The UAB Graduate Student Government, which has SOM representation, has allocated funds to a COVID-19 Emergency Grant Application. Students that qualify can receive up to $500 to assist with unexpected expense(s) caused by the ongoing COVID-19 situation. The money does not need to be repaid. 

www.uab.edu/gsg
https://www.facebook.com/uabgsg/photos/rpp.219969735656/10163691503065657/?type=3&theater

UAB Medicine recently opened additional testing facilities for COVID-19; prior to making an appointment to get tested, patients must call the UAB COVID-19 Call Center. MS3 and MS4 students volunteering at the call center use an online tool to determine whether individuals meet the criteria for testing and then schedule testing appointments. 

https://mailchi.mp/2762b03e8d31/health-equity-newsletter-covid-19-edition

Over 140 medical students have volunteered to help amplify important public health messages during the COVID-19 outbreak. Students use social media to share messages with their community about safe social distancing, whet no get tested, how to observe good hygiene, and overall - how to "flatten the curve"!

UAB School of Medicine got a call from Christ Health Center that they needed help returning blood test results for over 1500 people who were tested for Coronavirus (COVID-10). Over 100 members of the MS3 and MS4 classes signed up to help deliver the good news that these patients had tested negative and to date over 1400 patients have been contacted. 

Contact - Claire Finney (Office of Service Learning) clairefinney@uab.edu
Contact - Dr. Caroline Harada (Office of Service Learning) charada@uabmc.edu

UABSOM is organized into approximately 18-person learning communities; as we have transitioned to a mostly online curriculum, LC representatives and mentors have ensured that students are well taken care of and that students have appropriate resources. Additionally, online meetings have been established to provide community.

Contact - Dr. Caroline Harada (Office of Service Learning) charada@uabmc.edu

activities_info.details: Healthcare professional students are grouped into pods and paired with a healthcare worker's family to support their childcare needs. Contact: lacovidvolunteers@gmail.com

activities_info.details: UConn's Latino Medical Student Association is hosting a haiku competition for all members of the UConn Health community to help promote safe ways to stay connected. The topic of the haikus can be anything and a collection of these will be distributed to the UConn Health community after the competition is complete. Contact: Emily S. Lopez Santa; Email: elopezsanta@uchc.edu
UConn's Emergency Medicine Interest Group is connecting medical students with healthcare providers to coordinate child and pet care. Contact: Michael Martins; Email: mimartins@uchc.edu

UConn medical students and Farmington Community and Recreational Services are working together to gather volunteers to help the town's elderly residents and residents with disabilities. Volunteers have the option to grocery shop, deliver items, take grocery orders, be a conversation partner, do yardwork, and help with any future events. Contact: Purven Parikh; Email: pparikh@uchc.edu

activities_info.details:
HOPE- Helping Out Medical Education

Working to connect medical students with elementary, middle, and high school students of Miami-Dade County Public Schools to offer free, remote tutoring.

(Preliminary)

Initiative Lead: Matt Hey (M2)

Working with local hospitals and pharmacies to be able to deliver medications to patients in the community (especially vulnerable populations)

(Preliminary)

Homeless Population Initiative

Initiative Lead: Public Health and Preventative Medicine Interest Group and Dr. Gregory Schneider

(Preliminary)

Students in our Rotaract are working with Rotaract of Miami to buy meals from small business to give to healthcare workers and volunteers.

Initiative Lead: Matison Alderman (M2)

(Preliminary)

PPE Drive and Collection

Initiative Lead: Mackenzie Mayhew (M2)

Emory University School of Medicine

activities_info.details: A group of students are creating a peer reviewed, mobile pocket guide that summarizes the latest CDC and institutional guidelines on specific topics related to COVID-19. Visit the tool at https://c19guide.net. Led by Saumya Gurbin (sgurban@emory.edu).

Coordinated COVID education with content produced by medical students and peer reviewed by Infectious Disease fellows. Can be found on Twitter @JenniferSpicer4 and Instagram @Karen.ll.Law. Led by Caroline Coleman (Caroline.Coleman@emory.edu).
Students are volunteering to assist hospital pharmacies mail patients their medications. Contact Zach West (Zwest@emory.edu) or Anders Olsen (Timothy.A.Olsen@emory.edu).
Preventative health videos and worksheets for primary care patients created by medical students. Led by Hannah Ferrera (hmulvey@emory.edu)

Volunteer student assistance for medical residents and fellows with tasks such as babysitting, pet care, grocery store runs, etc. We are hoping to expand to more healthcare workers soon. Led by Zachary West (zwest@emory.edu).

Students are working with occupational health at the Atlanta VA. They plan on having multiple non-clinical projects that the VA needs assistance on during this pressing time. Contact Rachel Koch (Rachel.Lauren.Koch@emory.edu) or Rebecca Steinberg (RSstei2@emory.edu).

Proactive medical outreach for high risk patients.  Students are assisting with completing phone call health checks, COVID screens, and counseling to patients with upcoming or without recent medical care. Led by Alyssa Greenhouse (agree78@emory.edu)
Students have organized a virtual food drive in association with the Atlanta Community Food Bank supporting seniors and low income families. Led by Hayley Braun (Hayley.Braun@emory.edu).

10 for supplies to put in care packages for frontline healthcare workers. We partnered with a local volunteer organization who has been writing thank you notes for healthcare workers that they want to share. Organized by Aimee Vester (Aimee.Vester@emory.edu)

Students have started an initiative to address the needs of the Atlanta homeless shelter population by reaching out to homeless shelters and working with a local volunteer organization, "People's Response ATL." They are also coordinating PPE training for volunteers working on the front lines with vulnerable populations. Contact Troy Kleber (TKleber@emory.edu)
We have an initiative to assist in coordinating blood drives and increase public awareness of blood product shortages. Led by Stephen Gurley (Stephen.Andrew.Gurley@emory.edu)

A group of students have partnered with Psychiatry faculty and the National Alliance of Mental Illness to create an Instagram account (@COVIDMentalHealth) to share free/discounted mental health resources. They are also curating advice for COVID-19 related mental health and anxiety. Led by Ciara Hutchison (Ciara.Elizabeth.Hutchison@emory.edu) and Jennifer Li (JLi2245@emory.edu).

We have a group of students coordinating PPE collection from the community and delivering the PPE to local hospitals. We also have volunteers assisting with donation intake support for major hospitals. Led by Emily Trautner (Emily.Trautner@emory.edu)
Students are leading an effort to collect scrubs to deliver back to the hospitals for redistribution. Led by Cameron Blount (Cameron.Blount@emory.edu).
Yoga and meditation led by medical students and faculty live streamed on a daily basis. Led by Harrison Goodall (Harrison.Malone.Goodall@emory.edu).

activities_info.details:
Mercer Campus - Easter Cards for the Elderly:
This is an opportunity for medical students to create handmade Easter cards to deliver to local nursing homes here in town. Students can create cards on their own and contact Sarah Kate Chamberly to drop them off, or with any other questions.
Contact Name: Sarah Kate Chamberly
Email: sarah.kathryn.chambley@live.mercer.edu
Website: https://sites.google.com/view/musmcovid19/macon

Savannah Campus - 6 for Healthcare Workers:
Volunteer-run childcare system for employees of the hospitals affiliated with Mercer.
Contact Name: Lauren Yeargan
Contact Email: lauren.j.yeargan@live.mercer.edu
Website with Sign-Up: https://sites.google.com/view/musmcovid19/savannah/childcare-for-hcw

Macon Campus - 5 Volunteers
Link to Website: https://sites.google.com/view/musmcovid19/macon

Savannah Campus - American Red Cross 5 Volunteers
Volunteer to donate blood or to help register/screen donors.
Website: https://sites.google.com/view/musmcovid19/savannah/american-red-cross

Savannah Campus - Coastal Health District Department of Public Health
Volunteers are assisting with drive-thru testing and making phone calls to patients who have tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 and any of their contacts.
Contact Name: Marissa D'Souza
Contact Email: marissadsouzaa@gmail.com 
Website with Sign-Up: https://sites.google.com/view/musmcovid19/savannah/coastal-health-district-health-department

Columbus Campus - West Central Health District Health Department:
Volunteers are assisting with drive-thru testing and making phone calls to patients who have tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 and any of their contacts.
Contact Name: Sahil Patel
Contact Email: svp929@gmail.com
Website with Sign-Ups: https://sites.google.com/view/musmcovid19/columbus/west-central-health-district-health-department

Savannah Campus - Grocery Delivery:
Volunteers are delivering groceries to the elderly and immunocompromised to help decrease/minimize their contact with other individuals. Interested individuals should email covid19deliveryhelp@gmail.com for more details and further eligibility information.
Contact: covid19deliveryhelp@gmail.com
Website with Sign-Up: https://sites.google.com/view/musmcovid19/savannah/grocery-delivery-for-immunocompromised-individuals

Mercer Campus - Medical Mask Making:
A group of students volunteering to sew masks to send to various hospitals, Navicent health and Coliseum Medical Centers. Also sending masks to Phoebe Putney in Albany, GA. Sudents can create the masks on their own and contact Alyse Ragauskas to drop them off, or for more information.
Contact Name: Alyse Ragauskas
Email: Alyse.Maryelaine.Ragauskas@live.mercer.edu
Website (with link to instructions for making masks): https://sites.google.com/view/musmcovid19/macon

Savannah Campus - Medical Mask Making
Contact: musmcovidresponse@gmail.com
Website: https://sites.google.com/view/musmcovid19/savannah

activities_info.details: Medical student council created two forms: medical students listed what they were comfortable with providing (childcare for <12 months, 1-5 months, e-learning only, errands only, etc.) and the other form allowed physicians to list what they needed. A small group of students then paired physicians and students based on best match. This system helps protect student and physician information. Cases where physicians that had been in contact with COVID19 positive patients or had been in quarantine were managed on a case-to-case basis. Contact name: Christina Huang, chrhuang@indiana.edu; other student leaders assisting: Megan Chiu, Abigail Brenner, Rebekah Roll, Gabe Garena
Organized contacting Congress members about the measures needed during the pandemic via social media; Contact: Arvind Haran, arvharan@iu.edu
Organized homemade mask production and collection and organized PPE donation collection for local hospitals that were accepting, Contact: Maria Khan: khanmar@iu.edu
Contact: Aaron Gilani, asgilani@iu.edu

Tulane University School of Medicine

activities_info.details: We are using social media platforms and outreach within the school and community to document our efforts, engage the community, and gain support for PPE donations.

We are currently soliciting and accepting donations from the community, local businesses, and industry for personal protective equipment (PPE), which is in critically low supply at local hospitals due to the COVID outbreak. We are working with the school of medicine administration, local hospital administration,  and dedicated physicians from Tulane Medical Center and University Medical Center New Orleans (UMC).

Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, F. Edward Hebert School of Medicine
University of Maryland School of Medicine

activities_info.details:
Students will be providing help in various ways (running samples to lab, helping with data input, etc) to Employee Health Screening Clinics set to start running as soon as possible. Operating 7 days a week, students will take shifts.
No direct patient contact. 
Faculty physician contact: NidhI Goel ngoel1@som.umaryland.edu

15 students are helping gather information for UMMC's "Project Calvary," an initiative to gather data in the hospital on our various personel and their job experience & qualifications, should they need to change roles.
No direct patient contact. 
Faculty physician contact: NidhI Goel ngoel1@som.umaryland.edu

Students are assembling to help support the use of computer tablets in the hospital for telehealth. More and more providers in house are using tablets to communicate with patients remotely (when possible and appropriate) to minimize exposures. The students will be supporting this practice by monitoring the locations of the tablets, transporting them, and troubleshooting technical issues with them.
No direct patient contact. Devices will be cleaned before students handle them.
Faculty physician contact: NidhI Goel ngoel1@som.umaryland.edu

Students are being trained to supervise PPE use (i.e. donning and doffing) throughout the hopsital. They will then be taking shifts throughout UMMC to try to best utilize our existing PPE sources. No direct patient contact.
Faculty physician contact: NidhI Goel ngoel1@som.umaryland.edu

Students are volunteering to help with respiratory fit testing of N95 masks for hospital employees. Two six-hour shifts each day (this is day 3). No direct patient contact. 
Faculty physician contact: NidhI Goel ngoel1@som.umaryland.edu

Washington University in St. Louis School of Medicine

activities_info.details:
The goal is proactively prevent blood shortages, which are anticipated due to the cancellation of blood drives. The tasks involve increasing awareness for the American Red Cross individual blood collection appointments and possibly helping with any institution-sponsored blood collection efforts.

Contact: Christopher Chermside-Scabbo (ccherms@wustl.edu)

The goal is to supplement childcare for healthcare workers so that school and daycares closures do not detract from the healthcare workforce. We had over 100 provider responses in the St. Louis area within the first 24 hours, so we are now prioritizing front-line healthcare workers.

Contact: Christopher Chermside-Scabbo (ccherms@wustl.edu)

The goal is to develop specific plans for recovery that would be beneficial for the St. Louis community because almost all current efforts are focused on the immediate response. We are looking forward by studying how countries like China are managing their recovery efforts (i.e. preventing new waves of infection once the current one is under control) and applying these lessons to community initiatives that may help St. Louis after the initial surge.

Contact: Christopher Chermside-Scabbo (ccherms@wustl.edu)

Students will deliver donated food and groceries to St. Louis residents. Our primary community targets are high-risk groups, such as the elderly, immunocompromised, or currently quarantined individuals.
Triage e-mailbox to advise students/staff/faculty whether to self quarantine or return to work. Contact: Bruin Pollard (bruin.pollard@wustl.edu).
Volunteer support for the St. Louis County health department, including tracing contacts and investigating suspected COVID-19 cases. Contact: Bruin Pollard (bruin.pollard@wustl.edu).
We are actively promoting ourselves via Twitter, a national Slack channel that we started for med students, and our official website: studentcovid19response.wustl.edu
Support for spanish-speaking community through informational and educational videos to dispel common myths surrounding COVID-19. Contact: Bruin Pollard (bruin.pollard@wustl.edu).

The goal is to share and learn from other community service initiatives that are ongoing at other medical schools. We started a Slack channel, which now has ~650 medical students from around the nation/world to share best practices.

Contact: Cyrus Ghaznavi (cghaznavi@wustl.edu)

Each day, we prepare summaries of the most recent research on COVID-19 to share with physicians. The idea is that these summaries provide a quick overview of any new developments in the field, so that doctors can stay abreast of any relevant updates.

The goal is to procure personal protective equipment (PPE) from both internal and external (community) sources. We're working closely with the WashU Emergency Management to procure PPE with a special emphasis on masks and face shields.

Contact: Christopher Chermside-Scabbo (ccherms@wustl.edu)

The goal is to help relieve the burden of calling back and making notes for patients who test negative for COVID-19.

Contact: Jared Goodman (jvgoodman@wustl.edu)
Screening stations throughout hospital for all patients and visitors. Contact: Bruin Pollard (bruin.pollard@wustl.edu).

Cooper Medical School of Rowan University

activities_info.details: CMSRU students are sponsoring a blood drive in this time of desperate need for donations. Donating is considered an essential service and is encouraged for all who are able and feel healthy. Contact: doshis1@rowan.edu

Criti-call Connections Program has fourth-year students working with the Cooper University Hospital critic care team via telephone rounds, and relaying information to family members who cannot visit at bedside at this time. Students are there to provide updates, answer questions, and give further information to care teams.

Contact: Melissa Olsakowski, olsakowsm6@rowan.edu
CMSRU students are contacting local South Jersey businesses to secure gloves, masks, goggles and other items for Cooper University Hospital. Contact: Lauren Burgoon, burgoonL7@rowan.edu

Combating Social Isolation Via Virtual Visits During COVID-19 is a project inspired by students at Warren Alpert Medical School of Brown University. Medical students will reach out to residents at local assisted living and nursing homes to check in at a time when visitors are prohibited. Contact: Claudia Rugama, rugamac2@rowan.edu

node.name: Hackensack-Meridian School of Medicine at Seton Hall University
Rutgers New Jersey Medical School
Rutgers, Robert Wood Johnson Medical School

activities_info.details:
Healthcare Staff Support from RWJMS Students: Organizing student volunteers to support our healthcare staff by ensuring they are well supported outside of the hospital. Services include but are not limited to grocery shopping, virtual homework help, pet care, and dog walking. 

RWJMS Student Leaders: Sneha Swaminathan (sneha.swa@rutgers.com), Ardi Mendoza (anm156@rwjms.rutgers.edu), Aria Fariborzi (aaf119@rwjms.rutgers.edu), Olivia Dahl (osd7@rwjms.rutgers.edu)

Corporate Donations to Healthcare Staff - Work to assess the needs of healthcare workers on the frontlines, search for corporations willing to provide donations, and facilitate the logistics and delivery of said products. Additionally, work to bolster any areas of patient care that may be suffering as a result of the massive influx of hospital admissions linked to COVID-19, such as infection control and patient experience.

RWJMS Student Leader - Aria Fariborzi (aaf119@rwjms.rutgers.edu)

Telemedicine: Taking phone calls from community members who are ill with COVID or other undetermined URI. Helping with phone calls for follow up on discharged patients. 

RWJMS Leadership: Dr. Terregino Dean for Education and Academic Affairs, Associate Dean for Admissions (terregaca@rwjms.rutgers.edu), Dr. Catherine Chen (cmchen@rwjms.rutgers.edu)
RWJMS Student Leader: Kitae Cheng (kc923@rwjms.rutgers.edu)

5: Blood donations have plummeted with the COVID19 pandemic, while demand has increased. RWJUH is preparing for a blood/platelet shortage in the upcoming weeks, so students are organizing blood donation efforts amongst medical students. 

RWJMS Student Leaders: Samantha Cheng (sjc@rwjms.rutgers.edu), Mallika Tatikola (mt771@rwjms.rutgers.edu)

Promise Clinic Patient Support: Promise Clinic is a community clinic in downtown New Brunswick comprised of medical student doctors who provide healthcare services to the underserved and uninsured population. An extension of our Healthcare Staff Support Program is used to aid the patients who would be advised to self quarantine/socially isolate but do not have the means to do so because they cannot stock up on groceries/supplies. The student volunteers would help these patients through no-contact grocery/supplies delivery amongst other support. There is also a simultaneous fundraising effort initiated by Promise Clinic student doctors in order to provide food/supplies at no cost to the patients. 

RWJMS Student Leader: Catherine Morris (cjm403@rwjms.rutgers.edu)

PPE Donation: Students calling businesses for donations and coordinating pick ups/drop offs for high demand equipment to assist hospitals around NJ with ongoing shortages. 
NJCOVIDDonations@gmail.com

RWJMS Student Leaders: Erin Kern (erk63@rwjms.rutgers.edu), Danika Baskar (db978@rwjms.rutgers.com), Jacob Shamash(jcs378@rwjms.rutgers.edu)

Student 10 for Patient Focused Items - student led initiative to raise funds for items that patients may need while in the hospital or self isolating at home. 

RWJMS Student Leader - Sneha Swaminathan (sneha.swa@rutgers.edu)

PPE 10: "The Race to Get Protective Gear to NJ Hospitals" 
A coalition of medical students in NJ is working with an overseas supplier to provide VIC and NIOSH certified N95 masks. Estimated turnaround time is 10 days. Currently over $12000 has been raised via GoFundMe; https://youtu.be/cYwkg5VlKa4

RWJMS Student Leaders: Erica Concors (ec767@rwjms.rutgers.edu), Geethika Bhagavatula (gb449@scarletmail.rutgers.edu)

RWJMS COVID19 Innovation Task Force: The goal of this Task Force will be to harness the creative minds of those of us stuck sitting at home in order to workshop and innovate novel solutions to the COVID19 crisis currently plaguing our hospital, state, country, and world.

RWJMS Student Leaders: Gregg Khodorov (gik10@rwjms.rutgers.edu) and Biomedical Entrepreneurship Network
